title: Evaluating the effects of 'Best Practice' HRM in Local Government.
abstractText:
Aims

To examine the impact of best practice human resource management on public sector workers and organisational performance.

Objectives

  1. To evaluate the effects of best practice human resource management on performance outcomes in local government organisations;
  2. To test whether the outcomes of best practice human resource management can be regarded as beneficial to employers (organisations) and employees;
  3. To explain the different approaches taken to the adoption of best practice human resource management in local government organisations.

Brief description of research project

This research will evaluate the effects of ‘best practice’ human research management on individual and organisational performance outcomes in local government in Wales. The study will collect a range of outcomes of concern to both managers and employees through qualitative and quantitative research design. First a survey of staff attitudes and management practice will be undertaken across all participating local authority service departments. After analysing the survey data, a selected number of interviews with a cross-section of the workforce will be undertaken along with documentary analysis of policy directives. This approach is intended to provide context-specific information relating to HR practice and performance. As such, these data will assess whether HR practice leads to beneficial outcomes for organisations and workers – outcomes that have largely been assumed rather than empirically tested.
